metadata.title: BMP-3 is a novel inhibitor of both activin and BMP-4 signaling in Xenopus embryos
affiliations: Laboratory Manual. Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory

chunks.text: Introduction
chunks.chunk_summary: This section serves as a brief introduction.

chunks.text: Members of the TGF-B superfamily regulate crucial aspects of vertebrate development. This is particularly evident in Xenopus where the interplay between BMP and activin/nodal signaling is required for patterning during gastrulation. Activin/nodal-like ligands direct both the induction and specification of mesoderm and endoderm along the dorsal-ventral and anterior-posterior axes, while at the same time BMPs suppress dorsal and trunk mesoderm and neural fates (Harland and Gerhart, 1997; Kimelman and Griffin, 2000; Schier, 2003; Whitman, 1998).
chunks.section: Members of the TGF-B superfamily regulate crucial aspects of vertebrate development
chunks.chunk_summary: TGF-B superfamily members, especially BMP and activin/nodal signaling, are crucial for vertebrate development, particularly during Xenopus gastrulation, influencing mesoderm and endoderm formation.

chunks.text: Later in development, activins and nodals are key determinants in the establishment of left-right asymmetry and patterning of the nervous system while BMPs play a critical role in the formation of many tissues and organs including neural crest, heart, limb and skeleton (Hogan, 1996; Schier, 2003).
chunks.section: Members of the TGF-B superfamily regulate crucial aspects of vertebrate development
chunks.chunk_summary: Activins, nodals, and BMPs continue to play critical roles later in development, influencing left-right asymmetry, nervous system patterning, and the formation of various tissues and organs.

chunks.text: BMPs and activin initiate signaling through a cascade where ligands bind type I and type II receptor serine/threonine kinases on the cell surface (Massague and Chen, 2000). Upon activation, the type II receptor phosphorylates the type I receptor, which then phosphorylates receptor-regulated Smad proteins (R-Smads). These phosphorylated R-Smads complex with Smad4, move to the nucleus, and regulate target gene transcription alongside other proteins. R-Smads 2 and 3 are phosphorylated by activin-like ligands, while R-Smads 1, 5, and 8 are phosphorylated during BMP signaling (Massague and Chen, 2000; Miyazawa et al., 2002).
chunks.chunk_summary: BMP and activin signaling involves ligand binding, receptor activation, R-Smad phosphorylation, and nuclear translocation for gene regulation.

chunks.text: While BMPs and activins can bind to the same type II receptors (activin type II and IIB), they have distinct type I receptors, ensuring specific signal propagation through type I receptor/R-Smad pairings.  BMPs also signal through BMP-specific receptor complexes using BMPRII, a receptor not used by activin-like ligands (Massague and Chen, 2000; Miyazawa et al., 2002). This flexible ligand-receptor interaction allows BMPs and activins to act as multifunctional regulators in development and organogenesis. However, tight spatial and temporal control is crucial for signaling specificity.
chunks.chunk_summary: Distinct receptor usage ensures specific BMP and activin signaling, despite some shared receptors, enabling their multifunctional roles in development while requiring tight regulation.

chunks.text: The most common control mechanism for TGF-β-like signals occurs extracellularly, where antagonists like noggin, chordin, follistatin, gremlin, and cerberus block ligand-receptor binding (Balemans and Van Hul, 2002; Miyazono, 2000).  Further regulation happens at the cell membrane, cytoplasm, and nucleus of the target cell (Miyazono, 2000; von Bubnoff and Cho, 2001).
chunks.chunk_summary: TGF-β-like signaling is primarily regulated extracellularly by antagonists that prevent ligand binding, with additional control mechanisms at the cell membrane, cytoplasm, and nucleus.

chunks.text: BMP-3, a member of the TGF-B superfamily, has biological effects that oppose those of osteogenic BMPs and TGF-B1 in a variety of mammalian systems (Daluiski et al., 2001; Faucheux et al., 1997). In Xenopus embryos, we and others have shown that unlike BMP-2, BMP-4 and BMP-7, which are potent ventralizing agents, BMP-3 induces dorsalization (Daluiski et al., 2001; Hino et al., 2003). These effects of BMP-3 are most similar to the BMP antagonists noggin, chordin and follistatin, inhibiting the mesoderm-inducing activities of BMP-2 and ADMP in animal cap assays (Hino et al., 2003).
chunks.chunk_summary: BMP-3, unlike other BMPs, induces dorsalization in Xenopus embryos, similar to known BMP antagonists.

chunks.text: xBMP-3b, a molecule 83% homologous to xBMP-3, can also antagonize BMP-like ligands as well as nodal-like proteins (Hino et al., 2003). While these data identify BMP-3 and BMP-3b as novel antagonists in the BMP/TGF-β-signaling cascade, they do not give any clues as to how they might exert their effects.
chunks.chunk_summary: xBMP-3b also acts as a BMP antagonist, but the mechanism of action for BMP-3 and xBMP-3b remains unknown.

chunks.text: In this study, we examine the mechanism by which BMP-3 antagonizes TGF-β family ligand signaling in Xenopus embryos. We find that BMP-3 inhibits the mesoderm-inducing activities of both activin and BMP-4 by reducing the phosphorylation of R-Smads and that BMP-3 by itself is unable to activate BMP or activin R-Smads and thus does not signal using a TGF-β pathway. Inhibition by BMP-3 can be overcome by activated BMP or activin type I receptors or by increased levels of ActRIIB.
chunks.chunk_summary: This study investigates how BMP-3 antagonizes TGF-β signaling in Xenopus embryos by reducing R-Smad phosphorylation and its inhibition can be overcome by activated type I receptors or increased ActRIIB levels.

chunks.text: Finally, we find that BMP-3 binds to ActRIIB and that this binding cannot be competed by addition of excess activin. Our data support the hypothesis that BMP-3 is a novel TGF-β family antagonist that acts by interfering with activin and BMP binding to ActRIIB, a type II receptor common to both signaling pathways. By using this mechanism, BMP-3 is able to modulate diverse developmental processes that are controlled by both activin and BMP signaling at the level of the individual target cell, providing the embryo with additional means to regulate these signaling molecules.
chunks.chunk_summary: BMP-3 binds to ActRIIB, interfering with activin and BMP binding, thus acting as a TGF-β antagonist and modulating developmental processes controlled by activin and BMP signaling.

chunks.text: Materials and methods used in the research are described in this section.
chunks.chunk_summary: This section outlines the materials and methods employed in the study.

chunks.text: Embryo assays and microinjection were employed in this study.
chunks.chunk_summary: This study utilized embryo assays and microinjection techniques.

chunks.text: Xenopus embryos were generated, cultured, and staged using standard methods (Sive et al., 2000). RNAs were injected into the animal poles of 2- to 4-cell embryos or the ventral side of 4- to 8-cell embryos.
chunks.chunk_summary: This section describes the generation, culturing, staging, and RNA injection procedures used in Xenopus embryos.

chunks.text: Results are presented on page 3.
chunks.chunk_summary: This section presents the results of the study.

chunks.text: BMP-3 dorso-anteriorizes embryos.
chunks.chunk_summary: BMP-3 signaling plays a role in establishing the dorso-anterior axis during embryonic development.

chunks.text: In previous studies, we showed that BMP-3 mRNA injected on the dorsal side of Xenopus embryos had mild dorsalizing activity (Daluiski et al., 2001), producing a phenotype opposite to that of ventralizing BMPs. To investigate whether BMP-3 might antagonize BMP or other TGF-B-like ligand activity, we microinjected ventral vegetal blastomeres of 8-cell embryos with BMP-3 mRNA and looked for secondary axis formation.
chunks.chunk_summary: Previous research showed that BMP-3 mRNA injection in Xenopus embryos resulted in mild dorsalizing activity, prompting further investigation into its potential antagonism of BMP or other TGF-B-like ligand activity through secondary axis formation assays.

chunks.text: Strong dorsalizing factors like noggin, chordin, follistatin or dominant-negative BMP receptors (tBR) mimic the activity of Spemann's organizer and cause complete axis duplication in this assay (Harland and Gerhart, 1997).
chunks.chunk_summary: Known dorsalizing factors, such as noggin, chordin, and follistatin, mimic Spemann's organizer activity and induce complete axis duplication in the secondary axis formation assay.

chunks.text: The gain of function phenotypes observed align with the expression of xBMP-3 in specific regions of the Xenopus embryo, including the chordal mesoderm, notochord, and cement gland (Hino et al., 2003). These gain of function studies suggest that BMP-3 may contribute to dorso-anterior patterning by influencing gastrulation movements during Xenopus development.
chunks.section: The gain of function phenotypes we see are consistent with the expression of xBMP
chunks.chunk_summary: Gain-of-function experiments suggest BMP-3's role in dorso-anterior patterning during Xenopus development by influencing gastrulation movements.

chunks.text: BMP-3 induces cement gland and neural tissue in animal cap explants. This concise statement describes the effect of Bone Morphogenetic Protein 3 (BMP-3) on undifferentiated ectodermal tissue (animal cap) explanted from Xenopus embryos.  The observation that BMP-3 can induce both cement gland (an adhesive organ) and neural tissue in these explants suggests a role for BMP-3 in early embryonic patterning and cell fate specification.
chunks.chunk_summary: BMP-3 induces both cement gland and neural tissue in animal cap explants, suggesting a role in early embryonic patterning.

chunks.text: Next we tested the biological activity of BMP-3 in animal cap assays. When excised from blastula stage embryos, animal cap explants differentiate into epidermis. If the explants are treated with activin or nodal, they form mesodermal and endodermal tissues, while if exposed to BMP antagonists, they form neural tissue and cement gland (Harland and Gerhart, 1997).
chunks.section: Next we tested the biological activity of BMP
chunks.chunk_summary: Animal cap assays were used to test the biological activity of BMP-3, demonstrating that different treatments can induce the formation of various tissues.

chunks.text: Our results further indicate that BMP-3 has biological activities in Xenopus embryos that are similar to factors that inhibit both BMP and activin signaling, but that BMP-3 differs from previously described antagonists in that it induces cement gland and neural tissue, but not secondary axis formation or endoderm.
chunks.section: Our results further indicate that BMP
chunks.chunk_summary: BMP-3 in Xenopus embryos exhibits activity similar to BMP and activin signaling inhibitors, but uniquely induces cement gland and neural tissue without causing secondary axis formation or endoderm development.

chunks.text: BMP-3 blocks activin and BMP-4 mesoderm-inducing activity in animal cap explants. This short finding highlights the antagonistic relationship between BMP-3 and other BMPs like BMP-4, particularly in the context of mesoderm induction during embryonic development.  Animal cap explants, derived from the animal pole of amphibian embryos, serve as a model system for studying early developmental processes.  The observation that BMP-3 inhibits the mesoderm-inducing activity of both activin and BMP-4 suggests a regulatory role for BMP-3 in controlling cell fate decisions during early embryogenesis.
chunks.chunk_summary: BMP-3 inhibits the mesoderm-inducing activity of activin and BMP-4 in animal cap explants, suggesting a regulatory role in early embryonic development.

chunks.text: Using animal cap assays we tested the ability of BMP-3 to directly antagonize BMP and activin activity. When co-injected with RNA encoding BMP-4, BMP-3 was able to partially block the ability of BMP-4 to induce the expression of the early mesodermal marker, Xbra, as well as the ventral mesoderm marker, Xhox3.
chunks.section: Using animal cap assays we tested the ability of BMP
chunks.chunk_summary: BMP-3 partially blocks BMP-4 induced expression of mesodermal markers Xbra and Xhox3 in animal cap assays.

chunks.text: Induction of only anterior neural tissue in animal caps is a characteristic activity of BMP inhibitors (Harland, 2000; Weinstein and Hemmati-Brivanlou, 1999). Interestingly, BMP-3 appeared to induce this neural tissue directly, as we did not detect any expression of muscle actin, a mesodermal marker, even at high doses (1.5 ng) (Fig. 21).
chunks.section: Using animal cap assays we tested the ability of BMP
chunks.chunk_summary: BMP-3 induces anterior neural tissue in animal caps without mesodermal marker expression, suggesting direct neural induction rather than BMP inhibition.

chunks.text: Additionally, we saw that BMP-3 did not turn on the expression of molecular markers of endoderm, such as endodermin (Fig. 21) or Xsox17-ẞ (data not shown). Using animal cap assays, we also found that incubation of explants in BMP-3 protein resulted in the same phenotype as injecting BMP-3 mRNA.
chunks.chunk_summary: BMP-3 did not induce endoderm markers and protein incubation yielded similar results to mRNA injection in animal cap assays.

chunks.text: Cement gland and neural tissue were consistently induced when animal caps were cultured in hBMP-3-conditioned media (Figs. 2D and H).
chunks.chunk_summary: Cement gland and neural tissue were induced by hBMP-3-conditioned media in animal cap assays.

chunks.text: Our results further indicate that BMP-3 has biological activities in Xenopus embryos that are similar to factors that inhibit both BMP and activin signaling, but that BMP-3 differs from previously described antagonists in that it induces cement gland and neural tissue, but not secondary axis formation or endoderm.
chunks.section: Our results further indicate that BMP
chunks.chunk_summary: BMP-3 in Xenopus embryos exhibits activity similar to BMP and activin signaling inhibitors, but uniquely induces cement gland and neural tissue without causing secondary axis formation or endoderm development.

chunks.text: BMP-3 blocks activin and BMP-4 mesoderm-inducing activity in animal cap explants. This concise statement describes an experimental finding regarding the role of BMP-3 in mesoderm development.  Specifically, it indicates that BMP-3 inhibits the activity of both activin and BMP-4, two growth factors known to induce mesoderm formation, within animal cap explants, a common model system used in developmental biology.
chunks.chunk_summary: BMP-3 inhibits activin and BMP-4-induced mesoderm formation in animal cap explants.

chunks.text: Using animal cap assays we tested the ability of BMP-3 to directly antagonize BMP and activin activity. When co-injected with RNA encoding BMP-4, BMP-3 was able to partially block the ability of BMP-4 to induce the expression of the early mesodermal marker, Xbra, as well as the ventral mesoderm marker, Xhox3 (Fig. 3A).
chunks.section: Using animal cap assays we tested the ability of BMP
chunks.chunk_summary: BMP-3 partially blocks BMP-4 induced expression of mesodermal markers Xbra and Xhox3 in animal cap assays.

chunks.text: However, BMP-3 was not able to block the pro-epidermal activity of BMP-4. Figs. 3A-B show that expression of msx-1, a direct downstream target of BMP and a marker of ventro-lateral ectoderm, and epidermal keratin remained elevated in co-injected caps, indicating that BMP-3 interferes with the ventralizing activity of BMP-4 only in the mesoderm.
chunks.chunk_summary: BMP-3 does not block the pro-epidermal activity of BMP-4 but interferes with its ventralizing activity in the mesoderm.

chunks.text: In contrast to noggin, chordin or tBR which can rescue the BMP-4 ventralized phenotype in whole embryos (reviewed in Harland and Gerhart, 1997), we could not rescue ventralized BMP-4-injected embryos with co-injected BMP-3 (see Fig. 7G and data not shown).
chunks.chunk_summary: Unlike noggin, chordin, or tBR, BMP-3 cannot rescue the ventralized phenotype induced by BMP-4 in whole embryos.

chunks.text: These results show that in Xenopus, BMP-3 is a weak inhibitor of BMP when compared to other antagonists and suggest that BMP-3 may be blocking BMP activity using a novel mechanism.
chunks.section: These results show that in Xenopus
chunks.chunk_summary: In Xenopus, BMP-3 acts as a weak BMP inhibitor, potentially through a novel mechanism distinct from other antagonists.

chunks.text: We next investigated whether BMP-3 could antagonize activin signaling. When BMP-3-injected animal caps were incubated in activin protein, the morphogenic movements indicative of mesoderm induction were blocked (Fig. 3C).
chunks.chunk_summary: BMP-3 antagonizes activin signaling, blocking mesoderm induction in animal caps.

chunks.text: RT-PCR assays demonstrated that BMP-3 significantly inhibited activin mRNA and protein-induced expression of muscle actin, suggesting that BMP-3 can antagonize both activin and BMP signaling pathways.  The subsequent injection experiments build upon this finding.
chunks.chunk_summary: BMP-3 inhibits activin-induced muscle actin expression, suggesting antagonism of both activin and BMP signaling.

chunks.text: BMP-3 mRNA blocks activin protein activity, suggesting that BMP-3/activin heterodimers are not responsible for the observed effects in our assays. This aligns with previous data indicating that activin does not form heterodimers with other proteins.
chunks.chunk_summary: BMP-3 mRNA blocks activin protein activity, and the observed effects are not due to BMP-3/activin heterodimers, consistent with prior research.

chunks.text: BMP-4 (Wittbrodt and Rosa, 1994).
chunks.chunk_summary: This section mentions BMP-4, a growth factor involved in development and morphogenesis, citing Wittbrodt and Rosa (1994).

chunks.text: Finally, we wanted to determine if BMP-3 was acting as a general inhibitor of mesoderm induction in Xenopus. To do this, we tested the ability of BMP-3 to block mesodermal marker gene expression activated by Xnr1 (Xenopus nodal related 1), a TGF-β-like ligand shown to play important roles in mesoderm formation in early embryos (Schier, 2003) and by bFGF, a protein implicated in inducing and maintaining mesodermal fates in Xenopus (LaBonne and
chunks.chunk_summary: This study investigated the role of BMP-3 as a general inhibitor of mesoderm induction in Xenopus by examining its ability to block mesodermal marker gene expression activated by Xnr1 and bFGF.

chunks.text: Whitman, 1994; LaBonne et al., 1995). We found that injection of BMP-3 could not block the induction of Xbra by Xnrl supporting the previous findings of Hino et al. (2003) (Fig. 3E). In addition, we saw that BMP-3 did not effect the induction of muscle actin by bFGF protein (Fig. 3F).
chunks.chunk_summary: Injection of BMP-3 did not block Xbra induction by Xnrl, nor did it affect muscle actin induction by bFGF.

chunks.text: Our results confirm that in Xenopus, BMP-3 can only inhibit a subset of TGF-B family signals, including ventralizing BMP signals (BMP-2, -4 and ADMP) and now reveal that BMP-3 can also antagonize dorsalizing, activin signals.
chunks.chunk_summary: In Xenopus, BMP-3 inhibits a subset of TGF-B signals, including ventralizing BMPs and dorsalizing activins.

chunks.text: BMP-3 antagonizes activin and BMP signals upstream of receptor activation. This concise statement describes the inhibitory role of Bone Morphogenetic Protein 3 (BMP-3) on both activin and other BMP signaling pathways.  The key point is that this antagonism occurs before the signals reach their respective receptors, suggesting an early intervention in the signaling cascade.
chunks.chunk_summary: BMP-3 inhibits activin and BMP signaling pathways prior to receptor activation.

chunks.text: BMP and activin signaling are tightly regulated during embryonic development by potent extracellular antagonists that bind directly to these ligands, preventing them from interacting with their receptors. Extracellular antagonists can also inhibit signaling in an indirect manner, as has been shown for BMPs and noggin, where the ligand upregulates antagonist expression creating a negative feedback loop (Amthor et al., 1999; Gazzerro et al., 1998; Nifuji and Noda, 1999).
chunks.chunk_summary: BMP and activin signaling pathways are regulated by extracellular antagonists, both directly by preventing ligand-receptor interactions and indirectly through negative feedback loops involving molecules like noggin.

chunks.text: Existing data from our lab ruled out the possibility that BMP-3 itself was an extracellular ligand antagonist because we were unable to show direct binding of BMP-3 to other BMPs or activin (Daluiski et al., 2001 and L.W.
chunks.chunk_summary: Experimental evidence suggests that BMP-3 does not function as an extracellular ligand antagonist, as it does not directly bind to other BMPs or activin.

chunks.text: Gamer and V. Rosen (unpublished) investigated the possibility that BMP-3 influences development by regulating levels of known extracellular antagonists.  They assayed BMP-3-injected animal caps for increased expression of noggin, chordin, or follistatin.  Even at high doses (1.5 ng), BMP-3 did not induce expression of these antagonists in late blastula stage animal caps (Fig. 4A).
chunks.chunk_summary: Experiments showed that BMP-3 does not appear to function by upregulating known extracellular antagonists like noggin, chordin, or follistatin in Xenopus animal caps.

chunks.text: We next investigated whether BMP-3 could block the effects of constitutively activated type I activin or BMP receptors in the animal cap assay by looking for induction of mesodermal marker genes by these receptors. If BMP-3 acts intracellularly by interfering with receptor activation, we should observe a downregulation of mesodermal marker expression. Conversely, if BMP-3 inhibits signaling upstream of the receptor, marker gene expression should be unaffected.
chunks.chunk_summary: This study investigates whether BMP-3 blocks the effects of constitutively activated type I activin or BMP receptors by examining mesodermal marker gene expression in the animal cap assay.

chunks.text: For our experiments, we co-injected the constitutively activated activin type I receptor (CA-ALK4) or the constitutively activated BMP type I receptor (CA-
chunks.chunk_summary: The experiment involved co-injecting constitutively activated activin type I receptor (CA-ALK4) or BMP type I receptor.

chunks.text: ALK3) with BMP-3 into both animal blastomeres of 2-cell embryos. We then isolated animal caps and looked at the effects on mesodermal marker expression by RT-PCR. We found that BMP-3 was unable to block CA-ALK3 or CA-
chunks.chunk_summary: Investigating the effects of BMP-3 on mesodermal marker expression in animal cap cells injected with a constitutively active form of ALK3.

chunks.text: ALK4 from inducing the expression of Xbra or muscle actin (Figs. 4B and C). These data indicate that BMP-3 acts upstream of receptor activation before R-Smad phosphorylation by type I receptor.
chunks.chunk_summary: BMP-3 acts upstream of receptor activation, preventing ALK4 from inducing Xbra or muscle actin expression.

chunks.text: We then considered what receptor pathway BMP-3 could use to antagonize both activin and BMP signaling. We injected 4-cell embryos with BMP-3, BMP-4 or activin mRNA and examined R-Smad phosphorylation in isolated animal cap explants at stage 10.5. As expected, Western blot analysis showed strong phosphorylation of Smad1,5,8 by
chunks.section: We then considered what receptor pathway BMP
chunks.chunk_summary: This study investigated the receptor pathway used by BMP-3 to antagonize activin and BMP signaling by injecting embryos with mRNA and examining R-Smad phosphorylation.

chunks.text: BMP-4 and activin phosphorylate Smad2 (Figs. 5A and B), but surprisingly, BMP-3 alone did not phosphorylate any R-Smads (Figs. 5A and B, lane 3).
chunks.chunk_summary: BMP-4 and activin induce Smad2 phosphorylation, while BMP-3 alone does not phosphorylate R-Smads.

chunks.text: When we co-injected BMP-3 together with BMP-4 or activin, we found that BMP-3 decreased the level of phosphorylation of Smad1,5,8 and strongly reduced the phosphorylation level of Smad2 (Figs. 5A and B, lane 4).
chunks.chunk_summary: Co-injection of BMP-3 with BMP-4 or activin reduces Smad1,5,8 and Smad2 phosphorylation levels.

chunks.text: These results confirm that BMP-3 antagonizes signaling by activin and BMP and identifies BMP-3 as an inhibitor of signal transmission at the level of ligand binding to receptor.
chunks.chunk_summary: BMP-3 inhibits activin and BMP signaling by preventing ligand binding to the receptor.

chunks.text: Based on these findings, we also examined the effects of
chunks.chunk_summary: Following initial findings, further investigation was conducted.

chunks.text: BMP-3 overexpression on endogenous Smad phosphorylation in whole embryos was investigated.  It was found that BMP-3 strongly reduced the level of Smad2 phosphorylation but did not appear to affect Smad1,5,8 activation in gastrula stage 10.5 embryos. These data align with recent antisense morpholino experiments by Piepenburg et al. (2004), emphasizing the importance of activin signaling through Smad2 for early mesodermal patterning.
chunks.chunk_summary: BMP-3 overexpression reduces Smad2 phosphorylation but not Smad1,5,8 activation in gastrula stage embryos, supporting the role of activin/Smad2 signaling in mesodermal patterning.

chunks.text: Our results show that BMP-3 effectively blocks endogenous activin signaling by decreasing Smad2 activation but is less effective at blocking endogenous Smad1,5,8 phosphorylation. This difference in effectiveness may be attributed to the ability of BMPs to utilize both Smad-dependent and Smad-independent pathways.
chunks.chunk_summary: BMP-3 effectively blocks activin signaling via Smad2 but is less effective at blocking Smad1,5,8 phosphorylation, possibly due to BMPs utilizing both Smad-dependent and -independent pathways.

chunks.text: ActRII/B and BMPR-II are receptors used to transmit signals, while activin utilizes only ActRII/B.  BMP-3 blocks signaling at ActRII/B, suggesting that BMPs may still be able to induce signaling through BMPR-II.
chunks.chunk_summary: Different receptors (ActRII/B and BMPR-II) are involved in transmitting signals for BMPs and activin, and BMP-3's blocking of ActRII/B suggests alternative signaling pathways for BMPs.

chunks.text: Smad1,5,8 phosphorylation occurs through BMPR-II. These results led to an investigation of whether BMP-3 interacts with ActRII/B.
chunks.chunk_summary: This study investigated the interaction between BMP-3 and ActRII/B after observing Smad1,5,8 phosphorylation via BMPR-II.

chunks.text: BMP-3 binds ActRIIB.
chunks.chunk_summary: BMP-3 interacts with the ActRIIB receptor.

chunks.text: Having established that BMP-3 blocks both activin and
chunks.chunk_summary: BMP-3 inhibits both activin and an unspecified target.

chunks.text: BMP at the receptor level, the receptor targeted by BMP-3 would have to be one common to both the activin and BMP-signaling pathways, most likely the type II activin receptor.
chunks.chunk_summary: BMP-3 likely targets a type II activin receptor, shared by both activin and BMP signaling pathways.

chunks.text: ActRII/B has been reported to bind multiple ligands including BMP-2, BMP-7, GDF11 and activin (Massague and Chen, 2000). To look for an interaction of BMP-3 with
chunks.chunk_summary: ActRII/B binds multiple ligands, including BMP-2, BMP-7, GDF11, and activin, and the interaction with BMP-3 is being investigated.

chunks.text: ActRIIB, we co-expressed BMP-3 with epitope tagged. This short section mentions the co-expression of BMP-3 with an epitope tag in the context of ActRIIB.  While the exact experimental context is not fully clear from this brief snippet, it suggests an investigation involving ActRIIB, a type II receptor for BMPs (bone morphogenetic proteins), and BMP-3, a member of the BMP family. The use of an epitope tag implies that the researchers likely intended to track or isolate the expressed proteins for further analysis.
chunks.chunk_summary: BMP-3 was co-expressed with an epitope tag in an experiment involving ActRIIB.

chunks.text: ActRIIB (ActRIIB/Myc) was studied in early Xenopus embryos, using extracts from early gastrula stage animal halves for co-immunoprecipitation assays.  The results showed that BMP-3 co-precipitated with ActRIIB when using an anti-myc antibody (Fig. 6A, lane 3).
chunks.chunk_summary: Co-immunoprecipitation assays in early Xenopus embryos revealed an interaction between ActRIIB and BMP-3.

chunks.text: Since BMP-3 and activin can both bind ActRIIB, it is possible these two proteins compete for binding to their common receptor leading to the inhibition of activin signaling. To test this hypothesis, we performed binding competition assays in early Xenopus embryos. BMP-3 was co-expressed with ActRIIB/Myc in the absence or presence of increasing amounts (2 ng, 4 ng, 6 ng) of activin/HA and protein extracts of gastrula stage animal halves were immunoprecipitated with anti-myc antibody.
chunks.chunk_summary: This study investigates the potential competition between BMP-3 and activin for binding to the ActRIIB receptor in Xenopus embryos using binding competition assays and immunoprecipitation.

chunks.text: Fig. 6B shows that increasing amounts of activin/HA did not significantly decrease the amount of BMP-3 immunoprecipitated by
chunks.chunk_summary: The results presented in Figure 6B indicate that increasing activin concentrations did not significantly reduce the amount of immunoprecipitated BMP-3.

chunks.text: ActRIIB. The reverse experiment gave similar results with increasing doses of BMP-3 unable to significantly reduce the levels of activin immunoprecipitated by ActRIIB (Fig. 6C). Our data suggest that once BMP-3 binds the type II receptor, it cannot be competed off by excess activin. These results agree with our observation that animal caps preloaded with BMP-3 cannot respond to activin protein added later (see Figs. 3C and D).
chunks.chunk_summary: Experiments show that BMP-3 binds strongly to ActRIIB and cannot be displaced by activin, preventing activin signaling.

chunks.text: The interaction we observe may reflect the ability of BMP-3 and activin to bind to different sites on ActRIIB. Even if the two ligands do not compete for the same site on the receptor, binding of BMP-3 precludes signal transduction by the activin-ActRIIB complex. We did not perform these same competition experiments using BMP-4 as BMP-4 is known to prefer the type I receptor, and is unlikely to bind to type II receptor in the absence of type I receptor in vivo (Shi and Massague, 2003).
chunks.chunk_summary: BMP-3 binding to ActRIIB, potentially at a different site than activin, blocks activin signaling;  competition experiments were not performed with BMP-4 due to its preference for type I receptors.

chunks.text: We next looked to see how BMP-3 binding to type II receptor affected the recruitment of type I receptor to the receptor complex. To do this, BMP-3 was injected into
chunks.section: We next looked to see how BMP
chunks.chunk_summary: This study investigated how BMP-3 binding to its type II receptor influences the recruitment of the type I receptor to form the active receptor complex by injecting BMP-3.

chunks.text: Xenopus embryos with ActRIIB/Myc alone or with ActRIIB/ represent a model system for studying the role of ActRIIB receptor signaling. This truncated section likely refers to experiments involving manipulating the ActRIIB receptor, a type II activin receptor, in Xenopus embryos.  The mention of Myc suggests a potential focus on cell growth and proliferation, as Myc is a proto-oncogene involved in these processes. The incomplete nature of the provided text makes it difficult to ascertain the exact experimental setup and goals. However, it can be inferred that the study likely investigates the effects of altering ActRIIB signaling, potentially in combination with Myc manipulation, on developmental processes in Xenopus embryos.
chunks.chunk_summary: This section mentions the use of Xenopus embryos with manipulated ActRIIB/Myc expression to study ActRIIB signaling in development.

chunks.text: Myc and the type I activin receptor, Alk4/Flag and protein extracts were immunoprecipitated with anti-myc antibody.
chunks.section: Myc and the type I activin receptor
chunks.chunk_summary: Myc, the type I activin receptor Alk4/Flag, and protein extracts were immunoprecipitated using an anti-myc antibody.

chunks.text: We found that BMP-3 was able to make a complex containing both ActRIIB and Alk4 (Fig. 6D). Our data suggest this complex is inactive and prevents activin signal transduction.
chunks.chunk_summary: BMP-3 forms an inactive complex with ActRIIB and Alk4, inhibiting activin signal transduction.

chunks.text: To further evaluate and confirm our binding assay results, we performed rescue experiments using whole embryos in which BMP-3 mRNA was co-injected.

chunks.chunk_summary: Rescue experiments using BMP-3 mRNA injection in whole embryos were conducted to validate binding assay results.

chunks.text: In this report, we use the wealth of information about the activities of BMP and activin-like molecules in Xenopus to explore the mechanism used by BMP-3 to modulate these signals in the context of Xenopus development. Our data show that BMP-3 is a dorso-anteriorizing factor that antagonizes both activin and BMP-4 by binding to ActRII, their common receptor, and interfering with signal transduction. The interactions of BMP-3, activin and BMP-4 are outlined in Fig. 8.
chunks.chunk_summary: This study investigates the mechanism by which BMP-3 modulates BMP and activin signaling during Xenopus development, demonstrating its dorso-anteriorizing effect through binding to ActRII and interfering with signal transduction.

chunks.text: When activin and BMP-3 are both present, if BMP-3 occupies ActRII, activin is excluded, and an inactive receptor complex forms that blocks Smad2 phosphorylation. As a result, activin signaling in target tissues is diminished (Fig. 8C). This was shown in biochemical binding and competition assays as well as in our animal cap experiments, where BMP-3 prevented mesoderm formation by blocking activin phosphorylation of Smad2.
chunks.chunk_summary: BMP-3 inhibits activin signaling by competitively binding to ActRII, preventing Smad2 phosphorylation and subsequent mesoderm formation, as demonstrated by biochemical and animal cap experiments.

chunks.text: When BMP-4 and BMP-3 are both present, if BMP-3 occupies ActRII, Smad1,5,8 phosphorylation cannot occur through receptor complexes that contain ActRII (Fig. 8D).
chunks.chunk_summary: BMP-3 binding to ActRII prevents Smad1,5,8 phosphorylation through ActRII-containing receptor complexes when both BMP-3 and BMP-4 are present.

chunks.text: However, since BMP-4 is not bound by BMP-3, BMP-4 is able to activate BMP signaling through BMPR-II, allowing downstream signaling to occur. This suggests that BMP-3 acts as a selective inhibitor, specifically targeting BMP-2 and not BMP-4, thereby modulating the overall BMP signaling pathway and influencing downstream processes.
chunks.chunk_summary: BMP-3 selectively inhibits BMP-2 but not BMP-4, allowing BMP-4 to activate BMP signaling through BMPR-II.

chunks.text: BMP signaling is observed in cells expressing the BMP-specific type II receptor.  The co-injection of BMP-3 and BMP-4 into animal caps induces epidermal markers like msx-1 and epidermal keratin, supporting the role of BMP signaling in epidermal differentiation.
chunks.chunk_summary: Co-injection of BMP-3 and BMP-4 induces epidermal markers, suggesting a role for BMP signaling in epidermal differentiation.

chunks.text: Smad1,5,8 signaling is observed in whole embryos that overexpress these proteins. This brief observation suggests a role for Smad1,5,8 signaling in embryonic development, although the specific function and downstream effects require further investigation.  Further research is needed to elucidate the precise role of Smad1,5,8 signaling during embryogenesis and its contribution to developmental processes.
chunks.chunk_summary: Smad1,5,8 signaling is observed in overexpressing whole embryos, suggesting a role in development but requiring further investigation.

chunks.text: BMP-3 exhibited an interesting behavior in animal cap assays, demonstrating an inability to inhibit the activity of Xnr1 (Hino et al., 2003). Xnr1 is a ligand that signals through the ActRIIB/Alk4 pathway and necessitates an EGF-CFC co-receptor for its function (Cheng et al., 2003).
chunks.chunk_summary: BMP-3 was unable to block Xnr1 activity, a ligand that signals through ActRIIB/Alk4 and requires an EGF-CFC co-receptor.

chunks.text: Schier (2003) found relevant prior work. Based on our results, we conclude that BMP-3's potency as a TGF-B superfamily signaling antagonist is greatest for ligands acting directly through ActRII.
chunks.chunk_summary: BMP-3 most effectively antagonizes TGF-B superfamily ligands that signal through ActRII.

chunks.text: While our data identify BMP-3 as a receptor antagonist, there are additional ways in which BMP-3 might act to inhibit activin and BMP signaling. One intriguing possibility is that BMP-3 forms heterodimers with BMPs or activin, creating dominant-negative ligands. This is consistent with reports that injected BMP-3 can form heterodimers with BMP-2 in Xenopus embryos (Hino et al., 2003).
chunks.chunk_summary: BMP-3 may inhibit activin and BMP signaling by forming dominant-negative heterodimers with BMPs or activin, supported by evidence of BMP-3/BMP-2 heterodimer formation in Xenopus embryos.

chunks.text: Our animal cap assays show that BMP-3-conditioned media (which contains only BMP-3 homodimers) have the same biological activity as injected BMP-3 mRNA. We also observed that injected activin mRNA cannot rescue the
chunks.chunk_summary: Animal cap assays demonstrate that BMP-3 conditioned media (containing BMP-3 homodimers) exhibits the same biological activity as injected BMP-3 mRNA, and injected activin mRNA does not rescue this activity.

chunks.text: BMP-3 whole embryo phenotype. These results suggest that the BMP-3-antagonistic activity in our experiments is unlikely to be due to heterodimerization between BMP-3 and activin. It is still possible that BMP-3/BMP-2/4 or
chunks.chunk_summary: Experiments suggest that the observed BMP-3 antagonistic activity is not likely due to heterodimerization with activin, but potential interactions with BMP-2/4 remain possible.

chunks.text: BMP-3/activin heterodimers could form in Xenopus embryos and have their own receptor affinities that would allow for selective inhibition of a subset of TGF-B members. This is something we plan to investigate in future studies.
chunks.chunk_summary: The potential formation of BMP-3/activin heterodimers in Xenopus embryos and their selective inhibition of TGF-B members is proposed for future investigation.

chunks.text: Our gain of function studies with BMP-3 in Xenopus embryos support the idea that the biological actions of BMP signaling are context-dependent and can be modulated by other factors.

chunks.chunk_summary: Gain-of-function studies with BMP-3 in Xenopus embryos suggest that BMP signaling outcomes are context-dependent and can be influenced by other factors.

chunks.text: BMP signaling through ActRII. Selectively blocking ActRII may be an important way to affect specific developmental processes. For example, overexpression of BMP-3 in whole embryos causes the formation of enlarged and ectopic cement glands.
chunks.chunk_summary: Blocking ActRII can influence development, as evidenced by BMP-3 overexpression leading to abnormal cement gland formation.

chunks.text: In recent years, a model has been put forth suggesting that intermediate levels of BMP signaling in the ectoderm lead to cement gland formation, while high levels of BMP signaling promote epidermis and low levels of
chunks.chunk_summary: Different BMP signaling levels in the ectoderm are proposed to regulate the formation of cement glands and epidermis.

chunks.text: BMP signaling can result in neural tissue formation (Wardle and Sive, 2003). Our findings support this hypothesis: since BMP-3 doesn't fully block BMP signaling, cement gland tissue might be induced in embryos and animal caps due to moderate BMP signaling levels potentially occurring through BMPRII. Further supporting this concept, both BMP-3 and BMP-4 are expressed in the developing cement gland (Fainsod et al., 1994).
chunks.chunk_summary: Moderate BMP signaling, potentially through BMPRII, may induce cement gland tissue formation, supported by the expression of both BMP-3 and BMP-4 in the developing cement gland.

chunks.text: In gastrula stage embryos, BMP-3 transcripts are found throughout the marginal zone mesoderm where they appear to overlap with the expression of activin (Dohrmann et al., 1993; Fainsod et al., 1994; Hemmati-Brivanlou and
chunks.chunk_summary: BMP-3 transcripts are expressed in the marginal zone mesoderm of gastrula stage embryos, overlapping with activin expression.

chunks.text: Thomsen, 1995; Hino et al., 2003). This co-localization may allow BMP-3 to play a role in restricting activin in a cell-specific manner, so that once BMP-3 binds to ActRII it is unavailable to transmit activin signals, ensuring proper dorso-anterior mesodermal patterning.
chunks.chunk_summary: BMP-3 restricts activin signaling by binding to ActRII, contributing to proper dorso-anterior mesodermal patterning.

chunks.text: In addition, BMP-3 expression overlaps with BMP-4 expression in gastrula stage ectoderm (Fainsod et al., 1994; Hemmati-Brivanlou and Thomsen, 1995; Hino et al., 2003) where BMP-3 could act to decrease BMP signaling, allowing other BMP antagonists that are expressed in Spemann's organizer to successfully induce the full range of nervous system tissues.
chunks.chunk_summary: Overlapping expression of BMP-3 and BMP-4 in the gastrula stage ectoderm suggests BMP-3 may modulate BMP signaling, enabling other BMP antagonists to induce nervous system tissue development.

chunks.text: Although our gain of function studies indicate BMP-3 has a role patterning the Xenopus embryo, previously reported antisense morpholino oligonucleotide experiments for BMP-3 did not show any phenotype (Hino et al., 2003). Since BMP-3 acts as an antagonist, it may need to be ablated in conjunction with other activin/BMP inhibitors in order to determine its effects on embryonic development.

chunks.chunk_summary: Gain-of-function studies suggest BMP-3's role in Xenopus embryo patterning, but previous morpholino knockdown experiments showed no phenotype, possibly because BMP-3's antagonist activity requires ablation in conjunction with other inhibitors.

chunks.text: GDF-10) compensates for the loss of BMP-3 in early embryos, or that the role of BMP-3 in Xenopus development may be temporally restricted to later stages. These ideas are supported by data from BMP-3 null mice in which the bone phenotype is first evident postnatally (Daluiski et al., 2001) and from GDF-10 (BMP-3b) knockout mice that do not have any obvious phenotype (Zhao et al., 1999).
chunks.chunk_summary: GDF-10 may compensate for BMP-3 loss in early embryos, with BMP-3's role potentially restricted to later stages, as supported by mouse model data.

chunks.text: Future studies that focus on the effects of loss of BMP-3 in combination with other activin/BMP antagonists may allow us to determine its full role during development.
chunks.chunk_summary: Further research combining BMP-3 loss with other activin/BMP antagonists is needed to fully understand BMP-3's developmental role.

chunks.text: Our current data regarding BMP-3 signaling in Xenopus embryos agree with the work of Hino et al., 2003 who reported that BMP-3 antagonized ventralizing BMPs but not nodal-like ligands. However, our findings on how this antagonism occurs in Xenopus need to be reconciled with previously published observations in mammalian cell lines where BMP-3 activated a TGF-β/activin-responsive reporter and also inhibited BMP signaling downstream of the BMP type I receptor (Daluiski et al., 2001).
chunks.chunk_summary: BMP-3 antagonizes ventralizing BMPs in Xenopus, but this contrasts with mammalian cell line studies where it activates a TGF-β/activin reporter and inhibits BMP signaling downstream of the type I receptor.

chunks.text: The most likely explanation for these differences is that BMP-3 acts in a cell-context-dependent manner, similar to that observed for inhibin which is an effective blocker of activin signaling but only antagonizes BMP signaling in cell types that express the co-receptor betaglyan (Wiater and Vale, 2003). Another possibility is that the methodology employed in the mammalian cell assays in which ligand and receptor plasmids are transfected into unresponsive cells that are then used for reporter assays is not as reliable as utilizing...
chunks.chunk_summary: The discrepancies in BMP-3 activity may be due to cell-context-dependent action, similar to inhibin, or limitations of mammalian cell assays using transfected plasmids in unresponsive cells for reporter assays.

chunks.text: Xenopus embryos possess all the necessary signal transduction machinery for studying endogenous Smad activation (Fig. 5), a direct measure of TGF-β signaling. This makes them a suitable model for investigating the role of bioelectric signaling in this pathway.
chunks.section: Xenopus embryos that possess all of the signal transduction
chunks.chunk_summary: Xenopus embryos are a suitable model for studying bioelectric signaling's role in TGF-β/Smad pathway due to their complete signal transduction machinery.

chunks.text: In conclusion, our data best fit a model in which BMP-3 interferes with activin and BMP-4 binding to the type II activin receptor without activating R-Smads. As a consequence, signaling through activin and BMP receptor complexes that utilize ActRII is diminished.
chunks.chunk_summary: BMP-3 inhibits activin and BMP-4 signaling by binding to the type II activin receptor without activating R-Smads, thus diminishing signaling through ActRII-utilizing complexes.

chunks.text: Thus, BMP-3 joins a growing family of TGF-β-like molecules including inhibin (Wiater and Vale, 2003) and lefty (Chen and Shen, 2004; Cheng et al., 2004), which by virtue of their ability bind to TGF-ẞ family receptors and co-receptors but not activate signal transduction, serve as modulators of growth factor activity during embryonic development.
chunks.chunk_summary: BMP-3, along with molecules like inhibin and lefty, acts as a modulator of growth factor activity during embryonic development by binding to TGF-β receptors without activating signal transduction.
